Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Liquid Charging in Electrostatic Atomizers for Coating and Painting Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this proposal is to investigate the process of the generation of electrical charges at the nozzles of sprays. This work will be done in collaboration with an industrial partner, Spraying Systems Company (SSCo), a large international manufacturer of spray products with a well-equipped research lab near the University of Illinois at Chicago. The co-PIs already have an on-going collaboration with SSCo.

The motivation for the proposed research is to facilitate the commercialization of the electrostatic atomizers for coating and painting applications. Both of these applications would benefit significantly from the ability to control drop trajectories to avoid waste, provide precision deposition, and reduce the spread of hazardous materials. The proposed work aims at providing the understanding needed to achieve these performance characteristics. In addition, a low-cost computational model as a predictive tool for the design of these atomizers will be developed. The proposal includes concurrent studies based on theory, computation and experiments. This is a multiscale problem that will be tackled by theory to separate the analysis of the extremely thin near-electrode polarized layer, where an imbalance of charges exists, from the analysis of the electroneutral bulk flow with much larger dimensions. As a result of this separation, one would only need to solve for a Laplace equation (for the electric potential) along with the Navier-Stokes equations in the incompressible bulk flow. The solution of the Laplace and Navier-Stokes equations, which are coupled through the boundary conditions at the electrode, will be obtained numerically. Experiments are also proposed to (i) determine an empirical coefficient for the rate of reaction at the electrode surface, and (ii) provide data for validation of the computational model. The validated model will be implemented to conduct a detailed study on the effect of various parameters, such as the shape of the electrode. Collaboration with SSCo will provide experimental data for model validation and will facilitate the scale-up of the process. Broader impacts include industrial outreach and involvement of undergraduates and graduate students; creation of animations demonstrating the charging process. A successful electrostatic atomizer for non-conducting liquids will provide great advantages in sprays and coatings, which are materials that surround us and we use in everyday life.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
This GOALI project was a collaborative investigation between the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) and Spraying Systems Co. which was principally focused on modeling and fundamental study on electrostatic atomization for spray painting and coating applications. Traditionally, oil is sprayed by high-pressure nozzles or air-atomization nozzles, while heating the oil in case of high viscosity. All these approaches have high economic costs. By charging the oil inside the atomizer, electrostatic atomization technology removes the necessity to heat the oil or apply high pressures. The defined goals in this project were to develop an accurate computational model for the design of electrostatic atomizers, produce experimental database for the model development and validation requirements, and develop prototype electrostatic atomizers for commercialization. The numerical and experimental findings were used to fill the gap in fundamental understanding of the charging phenomenon inside the electrostatic atomizers.  

We have developed two separate fundamental theories that can be integrated together in order to characterize the constituted near-electrode layers. The constituted layer attached to the conducting electrode is called the compact Stern layer. There were no previous theories to explain the characteristics of the compact stern layer including the thickness and the potential drop across this layer. The only notable previous study had correlated these two parameters without being able to quantify them independently. Our theory fills the gap and provides two independent approaches to characterize this layer comprehensively for high voltages.

The comprehensive knowledge on the constituted near-electrode layers is crucial for the developed computational model addressing the internal electrohydrodynamic flow. The computational model starts at the interface of the compact layer and the remaining constituted layers. The developed computational model and ensuing OpenFOAM solver address the faradaic reaction happening at the conducting electrodes and provides a detailed distribution of ions and charge density along the atomizer as well as the amount of charge at the exit surface of the atomizer known as the spray current. The provided OpenFOAM solver is available on a repository page in the OpenFOAM wiki website to assist other researchers in the field to continue development. The following is the link to our open source code available in OpenFOAM wiki repository:

https://openfoamwiki.net/index.php/Extend-bazaar/solvers/multiphase/EHDIonFOAM

The accompanying figure demonstrates the dimensionless flow field and charge density inside the atomizer from our preliminary three-dimensional simulation.

The experimental investigations were focused on measuring the current-voltage relations based on distinct operational conditions. The applied voltage versus the measured current density at the electrode surface was correlated. This function follows the well-known Frumkin-Butler-Volmer equation. Parameters such as the relative humidity, electrode material, and operating temperature were considered to produce the experimental database. Also, a novel method of measurement of electrical conductivity in oils was developed. The method is simple, straightforward yet is sensitive for the measurement of a wide range of electrical conductivity. The effect of different micro-constituents in vegetable oil on electrical conductivity was determined, thereof. It was found that the water content in oil plays an important role in electrode reactions and the overall conductivity of oil. This understanding led to studies on the effect of atmospheric humidity on electrical characteristics of vegetable oil and its implications on electrostatic atomization.

The GOALI project provided opportunities for three UIC MS students to gain on-site training at the Spraying Systems Co. These students were all supported financially by the company during their MS study at UIC and one of them is now employed at SSCo. In addition, three Ph.D. students worked on this project at UIC and were partially funded by this NSF grant. These students had access to the facilities at SSCo. for their studies. Also, one under-graduate student conducted a summer internship on this topic in Mashayek?s lab. The company developed two protypes of electrostatic atomizer for future commercialization.

The findings of this project including the developed theories, computational solver and the experimental data have been actively disseminated through technical conferences and peer-reviewed journals. There has been a total of 7 journal publications and 11 conference presentations from the findings of this project.

Modified by: Farzad Mashayek

    3D simulation of flow inside electrostatic atomizer
